sections.title: Gum disease
sections.body:
Gum disease is a common condition that affects the tissues supporting the teeth.

It often develops gradually and may not cause pain in its early stages, which means it can progress unnoticed for some time.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, gum disease is managed with a long-term view, focusing on understanding causes, stabilising the condition, and supporting ongoing oral health.

It often develops gradually and may not cause pain in its early stages.
Care focuses on understanding causes, stabilising the condition, and supporting ongoing oral health.

sections.title: Why gum health matters
items: Healthy gums provide essential support for teeth.
When gum disease progresses, it can compromise tooth stability and affect long-term oral health.
Managing gum health helps protect existing dental work and reduces the risk of future problems.
The aim is stability rather than perfection.

sections.title: What gum disease is
sections.body:
Gum disease occurs when bacteria build up around the teeth and gums, leading to inflammation and damage to the supporting tissues.

In its early form, known as gingivitis, the gums may bleed or appear swollen. If left untreated, it can progress to periodontitis, where bone and supporting structures are affected.

Not everyone progresses at the same rate, and severity varies between individuals.
bullets: Bacteria build-up can lead to inflammation and damage to supporting tissues.
Gingivitis may cause bleeding or swollen gums.
Periodontitis affects bone and supporting structures if untreated.

sections.title: Common signs and symptoms
items: Gum recession, loose teeth, or changes in bite.

sections.title: Assessment and diagnosis
items: Assessment involves examining the gums and measuring gum health around the teeth.
We review X-rays where appropriate and consider individual risk factors.
This helps determine the stage of gum disease and the most appropriate management approach.
Findings are discussed clearly so you understand what they mean for you.
sections.strapline: Findings are discussed clearly so you understand what they mean for you.

sections.title: Management and treatment
sections.body:
Treatment for gum disease focuses on reducing inflammation and controlling bacterial build-up.

This may involve professional cleaning, tailored oral hygiene advice, and regular monitoring.

Management is usually ongoing rather than a one-off intervention.

sections.title: Maintenance and review
items: Long-term gum health depends on consistent care and review.
Regular appointments allow us to monitor stability and address changes early.
We adjust care as needed over time.
This ongoing approach helps maintain comfort and function.

faqs.question: What does gum disease mean?
faqs.answer: Gum disease is a common condition that affects the tissues supporting the teeth. It often develops gradually and may not cause pain in its early stages.

faqs.question: Why is regular assessment important?
faqs.answer: Some people experience very few symptoms, which is why regular assessment is important. Clear understanding helps support long-term confidence and realistic expectations.

faqs.question: What does management involve?
faqs.answer: Treatment focuses on reducing inflammation and controlling bacterial build-up through professional cleaning, tailored oral hygiene advice, and regular monitoring.

faqs.question: What’s the aim of treatment?
faqs.answer: The aim is stability rather than perfection. For many patients, maintaining comfort and preventing further progression is a realistic and successful outcome.
